Finally, it prints ans.

write(str_ans, '(I0)') ans

Then, the first character is str_ans(1:1). But we have to be careful about leading spaces.

The length of the string is 20, which is more than enough for any reasonable N (since the first program's ans is the sum of digits of numbers up to N, which for N up to, say, 1e9 would have a sum of digits up to 9*9=81, so the string length is sufficient).

Wait, in Fortran, characters can be treated as integers via ichar and char functions. So:

result_char = char(char_val) Then print that character. Putting it all together.

children.text: Compute the minimal sum (ans) as per first Java program. Convert ans to a string.
children.label: language_mapping

children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Then, in the main program:

Read N.

Compute n.

Initialize ans.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Loop over A from 1 to n, compute current sum, track the minimum. Then process the ans as per second program. Now, code:

PROGRAM main
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER :: N, ans, A, n, current
    INTEGER FUNCTION sum_digits(a)
        INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: a
        INTEGER :: temp, res
        res = 0
        temp = a
        DO WHILE (temp > 0)
            res = res + MOD(temp, 10)
            temp = temp / 10
        END DO
        sum_digits = res
    END FUNCTION sum_digits

    ! Read N
    READ(*,*) N

    ! Compute n
    IF (MOD(N,2) == 0) THEN
        n = N / 2
    ELSE
        n = (N + 1)/2
    END IF

    ! Initialize ans
    ans = sum_digits(1) + sum_digits(N - 1)

    ! Loop over A from 1 to n
    DO A = 1, n
        current = sum_digits(A) + sum_digits(N - A) IF (current < ans) THEN
            ans = current
        END IF
    END DO

    ! Now process the ans as per second program
    CHARACTER(LEN=20) :: str_ans
    WRITE(str_ans, '(I0)') ans
    INTEGER :: first_char_ascii
    first_char_ascii = ICHAR(str_ans(1:1)) + 1
    CHARACTER(LEN=1) :: result_char
    result_char = CHAR(first_char_ascii)
    WRITE(*, '(A)') result_char

END PROGRAM main

A=4:4+6 →10.

A=5:5+5 →5+5=10. So ans remains 10. Then the second program takes "10" as input, first character is '1', adding 1 gives '2', so output is '2'.

FUNCTION sum_digits(a) RESULT(res)

END FUNCTION sum_digits

FUNCTION sum_digits(a) RESULT(res)
    INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: a
    INTEGER :: res, temp, digit
    temp = a
    res = 0
    DO WHILE (temp > 0)
        digit = MOD(temp, 10)
        res = res + digit
        temp = temp / 10
    END DO
END FUNCTION sum_digits

    int ans = 0;
    while (a >= 10) {
        ans += a % 10;
        a /= 10;
    }
    ans += a;
    return ans;
}

PROGRAM main
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER :: N, ans, A, n, current
    INTEGER FUNCTION sum_digits(a)
        INTEGER, INTENT(IN) :: a
        INTEGER :: temp, res
        res = 0
        temp = a
        DO WHILE (temp > 0)
            res = res + MOD(temp, 10)
            temp = temp / 10
        END DO
        sum_digits = res
    END FUNCTION sum_digits

    ! Read N
    READ(*,*) N

    ! Compute n
    IF (MOD(N,2) == 0) THEN
        n = N / 2
    ELSE
        n = (N + 1)/2
    END IF

    ! Initialize ans
    ans = sum_digits(1) + sum_digits(N - 1)

    ! Loop over A from 1 to n
    DO A = 1, n
        current = sum_digits(A) + sum_digits(N - A)
        IF (current < ans) THEN
            ans = current
        END IF
    END DO

    ! Now process the ans as per second program
    CHARACTER(LEN=20) :: str_ans
    WRITE(str_ans, '(I0)') ans
    INTEGER :: first_char_ascii
    first_char_ascii = ICHAR(str_ans(1:1)) + 1
    CHARACTER(LEN=1) :: result_char
    result_char = CHAR(first_char_ascii)
    WRITE(*, '(A)') result_char

END PROGRAM main
